explanation:
The report is not correct for two reasons. First, MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17, as quoted, is specifically concerned with the functions from <string.h> (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.). The code in question calls snprintf, which is from <stdio.h>, not <string.h>, so that specific rule does not directly apply to these calls.

Second, the scenario described (len == sizeof(sock->stream_name), passing &sock->stream_name[len] — a one-past-the-end pointer — with a size argument of 0 to snprintf) is allowed by the C standard: when the size argument is zero, the destination pointer may be a null (or otherwise non-dereferenceable) pointer and the function must not attempt to write to it. Thus passing a one-past-the-end pointer together with a zero size does not by itself invoke undefined behavior under the C standard and is not a <string.h>-function bounds violation covered by MISRA Rule 21.17. (If a project wants to be extra defensive or to satisfy some static analysers, a guard such as testing len < sizeof(sock->stream_name) before calling snprintf can be added, but that is a coding-style/defensive measure rather than a requirement under MISRA 21.17.)
